div1.p: Moran discusses the remains of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, October 16, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, Oct. 16, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I am inclosing statements, declarations, observations, etc.
made by Sra. Maria Teresa Loma Vda. de Rojas and by Dr. Perez Beato,
translated from Spanish by Mrs. Phillips. The latter, unfortunately,
did not make a very good translation and notwithstanding my caution that
the translation be made verbatim, she corrected the entries as written
by Dr. Rojas in his Journal, correcting proper names, such as that of
“Lezar” to read “Lazear”. In his entries, Dr. Rojas did not spell the
name correctly until that for September 29, 1901, where he uses, for the first
time and correctly the name of Lazear and the name of the Camp in English,
“Camp Lazear”. Also, the first check received by him, January 2, 1901,
was remitted to him by Major Reed, whose surname he spelled “Read”. In the
entries for September 29, 1901, and October 1, 1901, the name Lazear is
spelled correctly, not so in the previous entries. You get what I mean.
I wanted Mrs. Phillips to mis-spel in the translation what Dr. Rojas mis-
spelled in his own handwriting. She evidently overlooked that little detail
and I did not want to trouble her to do it all over again. I will try to
get out a better translation and take it up with me. In the meantime, should
you want to make use of the entries, you may take note of the preceding
observations, if you are in accord with me that the original entries should
not have been corrected or altered in any way.

What the shacks were used for and by whom they were occupied
between October 9th, 1901, is not known. According to the record, Zun-
zunegui's father did not take over the limekilns until March, 1907. Z.
says he lived in the shacks from 1903 on. While his father may have
been employed on the farm in some other capacity, without contract with
Dr. Rojas, there is nothing to prove it. At the same time it is barely
possible that his father was allowed, perhaps as a farmhand, to occupy the
shack.

Will take the photostats up with me UNLESS YOU CABLE ME, ON
RECEIPT OF THIS LETTER, TO AIRMAIL THEM TO YOU. In the meantime, I will
have the entries properly translated, securing Sra. Rojas' signature to
the translations, if at all possible.
